generated_json.title: History of Present Illness
content: The patient reports daily pain in the lower back and bilateral legs. The pain has been persistent and ongoing, with no significant improvement despite use of supportive measures such as braces and over-the-counter pain relief. The patient describes a history of a detached disc on one side and a torn disc on the other side of the lumbar spine. They currently use braces for ambulation, particularly during activities such as walking in hilly terrain. The patient is retired and not currently working. They express interest in physical therapy as a treatment option and are open to further interventions, including an MRI and potential epidural injection. The patient has not received any new medications from the provider during this visit. They previously used Tylenol and warm baths for symptom management. The patient is concerned about the need for an MRI and the timeline for treatment approval. They are awaiting approval for an injection, which the provider explains may involve sedation and temporary incapacitation. The patient is scheduled to return in October for follow-up.
generated_json.instruction:

Document any prior treatments or remedies the patient has attempted, noting their efficacy. Describe how these symptoms impact the patient's daily activities, overall well-being, and quality of life. sub-section.title: Plan
content: Schedule MRI of the lumbar spine to evaluate current disc pathology and nerve root involvement
Initiate physical therapy for strengthening and pain management
Consider epidural steroid injection for pain relief, pending insurance approval
Prescribe oral analgesics (e.g., acetaminophen) for pain management as needed
Educate patient on the importance of timely check-ins and communication with the care team
Coordinate with insurance for approval of MRI and injection procedures
Monitor for signs of improvement or complications during follow-up
